subject: Re: [junit] Clarifying how to use unit tests
msgSnippet: ... Rakesh, It s really cool that you ve tried TDD and found it exciting.  I hope that you can quickly figure out something that feels like the right thing.
messageBody:
Quoting Rakesh Patel <rakesh.mailgroups@...>:

> However, the tests that result from TDD are NOT unti tests. They are
> actually quite high-level. I found dropping out of TDD into unit testing
> quite hard and unnatural. Even though the resulting tests are important
> to have, i couldn't help feeling that by not writing the lower-level
> unit tests (against say a private method) I was not doing the right thing.

Rakesh,

It's really cool that you've tried TDD and found it exciting. I hope that you
can quickly figure out something that feels like the right thing.

Just to clarify, it sounds like you write a test for some functionality that
feels high-level, and then find it fairly easy to quickly write the code that
makes it pass, but at the end, find yourself with methods that appear to be
tested only through tests exercising methods somewhere higher up the call
chain, and you feel that it would be important to have tests against those
lower-level methods.

There are several situations that can drive me to have two "levels" of tests.
However, I don't hit these situations on all projects:

1) Running all the high-level tests takes longer than my attention span
(somewhere around 30 seconds on good days, for me).
2) It takes a long time to get each high-level test passing (I definitely get
jumpy after an hour.)
3) I can easily think of bugs in the lower-level methods that would not be
caught by the higher-level tests.

Notice that I might run into situation 1 after I had been working on a program
for a while. However, I try to catch situations 2 and 3 as soon as
possible--they indicate that I need to adjust the "pacing" of my test-driven
development toward more smaller tests.

When I have two levels of tests, it is often the case that I actually have two
failing tests at a time: one high-level failure, and one related low-level
failure.

I hope that helps.

David Saff
